SafetyInspectionBy: LARA Bureau of Fire Services State Fire Marshall

HCl monitors in tank dike, sump LSH

Implementing Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) gap closure measures

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Automatic foam supplied to deluge system

HCL and Chlorine monitors.  EVE dike drains to fire pit with LSH monitor in sump.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Automatic foam supplied to deluge system
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: LEL, Cl2, HCL, Propylene, Ammonia detectors

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2014 General Executive Summary for The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site Midland, Michigan.



Revisions to the Plan



Revisions to the December 22, 2010 plan are being submitted on June 30, 2014 for the following reasons:



1.    Interconnectivity

?    For the sake of completeness, Dow is listing new substances for several processes that are interconnected by interplant pipeline to sources in remote locations.  Those sources consist of the Chemical Distribution and Methocel (TM) cellulose ethers processes.   Chemical Quantity (lbs) is a required data entry field within the e-Submit application.  To complete this entry in the plan, the Chemical Quantity listed for Chemical Distribution and Methocel (TM) include the maximum inventories for both storage and the interplant pipelines.  The Chemical Quantity for the interconnected processes will be the same as the Chemical Quantity reported for the Chemical Distribution or Methocel process, plus any storage at the interconnected process itself.  It is important to understand that this is a duplicate entry for the purposes of completing the electronic submission of the plan and does not mean Dow has increased the actual quantity present at the stationary source. 



?    Several processes were previously listed in the plan but now have new substances over the threshold quantity due to interconnectivity.  These include the following:

?    963 Ion Exchange Anion/Special Resins

?    374 Methocel (TM) cellulose ethers

?    298 Ethocel (TM) cellulose ethers

?    941 DAS Specialty Intermediates

?    948 DAS Phenoxy Herbicides

?    1028 DAS Sulfonamides



?    Three new processes will also be added to the plan due to interconnectivity only.  These include the following:

?    1 DAS Batch Plant 

?    858 DAS Dursban (TM) insecticide

?    588 Specialty Monomers 



2.    The following processes are being added to the plan for the reasons listed below.  

?    680 Sulfonamides:

o    The process previously had Vinyl Ethyl Ether present below the threshold

quantity but due to a planned increase in production now has the potential to be present above the threshold.

o    For the sake of completeness, the process will also be listing hydrogen chloride as a regulated substance due to interconnection to the larger source at the Chemical Distribution process.



o    768/477 AEM Manufacturing - The process previously had Bromine present below the threshold quantity but due to a planned increase in production now has the potential to be present above the threshold.



3.    Removal of the following process for the reasons listed below:

a.    Pharma 1200 process was shut down and is no longer part of the stationary source. 



4.     Removal of the following RMP regulated substances as they are no longer used at the stationary source:

?    Epicholorhydrin

?    Vinyl Chloride

?    Ethylene Oxide

?    Isopropyl Chloroformate

?    1, 3 Pentadiene





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  Appropriate controls are implemented to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  The facility also coordinates with the City of Midland Fire Department which can provide additional emergency response expertise.





Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site's primary activity is chemical manufacturing, including agricultural and specialty chemicals and plastics.  There are nineteen covered processes and fifty regulated substances present at the facility.  



T

he regulated substances are listed in Table 1 below.  Twenty of the chemicals in the list below are not routinely stored on site and/or if present are present in less than threshold amounts, but have been added under the provision of predictive filing.  Predictive filing was done for flammable or toxic chemicals which may be included in mixtures received at the facility.

Table 1:  Regulated chemical substances at Midland, Michigan Operations Site, including chemicals listed for predictive filing.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release p

revention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable company and governing agency requirements of the time of construction.  Modifications to existing structures are also done in compliance with applicable company standards and governing agency requirements.  Several processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 19 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site.





Process Safety Information



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site maintains detailed records of safety information that, among other things, describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all covered processes.  Numerous types of information are available to supplement safety information, including Material Safety Data Sheets for materials used on site, equipment and engineering design specifications and applicable reactive chemicals testing.





Process Hazard Analysis



The facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  For initial screening and risk evaluation, calculations of The Dow Chemical Fire and Explosion and Chemical Exposure Indices are performed, and a Reactive Chemical and Process Hazard Analysis is conducted.  These methodologies are supplemented when needed with analyses that may include:  What if Analysis, Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), and Fault Tree Analysis.  A team of qualified personnel performs the studies along with expertise in engineering and process operations.  Any findings related to the hazard analyses are addresse

d in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures



For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.





Training



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.





Mechanical Integrity



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel receive specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.





Management of Change



Written procedures are in place at The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training on the modification.





Pre-startup Reviews



Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established

processes are conducted as a regular practice at The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.





Compliance Audits



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule and other applicable regulatory requirements are being followed and have been implemented properly.  Audits are conducted using an established schedule for the site.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.





Incident Investigation



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root causes leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  The facility also investigates minor and near miss type of incidents as a preventive measure.





Employee Participation



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site operates on the premise that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues, to attend applicable reviews, and to recommend improvements.  Improvements are solicited and implemented as appropriate.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.





Contractors



On occasion, The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough eva

luation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  The facility has a strict program for informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes, as well as the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors are also required to inform the facility of any hazards they may introduce or encounter while at the site.







Five-year Accident History



There were no reportable accidents involving RMP chemicals that occurred at this facility within the past five years.





Emergency Response Plan



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan documents all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is updated as necessary to reflect any pertinent changes within the processes at the facility that would require a modified emergency response.



The facility works with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the facility emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced in order to ensure that it is functioning properly at all times.  





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the accidental release prevention program.  Development of Environmental Health and Safety Work Processes, a concentrated Behavior Based Safety effort, and company-wide Environmental Health & Safety goals are some of the major steps taken to improve safety at the facility.  The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the C
